title: Thursday, 6th April, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Hi there

PM11:01am

All a bit jittery, innit?

PM11:01am

Though damage to the Footsie limited

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Trump still gobsmacking

PM11:01am

Trying to make his meeting with Xi as uncomfortable as possible

PM11:02am

Suddenly waking up to Syria

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Not to mention N Korea

PM11:02am

I don't know

PM11:02am

It's enough to make you go and buy gold

11:02 am
PM11:02am

We generally avoid gold on here.

PM11:02am

Cos it attracts wingnut commenters

PM11:03am

Almost as many as blockchain

11:03 am
PM11:03am

But, on the basis that the wingnuts think we don't do gold, let's do some

PM11:04am

(Watch it, Sterni)

PM11:04am

Ok

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Joni Teves, UBS

PM11:05am

We temper our gold price forecasts, but maintain the positive narrative

PM11:05am

We have been bullish on gold for some time given expectations of 1) a moderate rates
environment, 2) a weaker dollar against DM currencies, and 3) broader macro
uncertainty encouraging diversification into gold. We think these factors remain
supportive of higher gold prices. Moreover, lean gold positioning suggests that there
should be ample room for gold allocations across a wider, more diverse set of investors
to grow. But while our core view is unchanged, we think that market developments
over the past several months do warrant some recalibration of our price expectations.
Firstly, the pick-up in gold interest in Q1 was slower than we expected. Secondly, a
faster pace of Fed tightening than previously expected presents downside risks for gold,
although more from the impact on sentiment than how we expect Fed policy to
ultimately affect rates. And finally, we think there could be some downside price risks
for gold coming from Europe – higher EUR yields, especially as political uncertainty
clears and data continues to improve, could in turn exert upward pressure on global
yields. We temper our gold price expectations across our forecast period. We now
expect an average of $1300 for 2017 from $1350 previously and an average of $1325
for 2018 from $1450 previously.

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Macro developments likely to remain key price drivers

PM11:06am

Our analysis suggests that US real rates and the dollar are currently key price drivers for
gold. Indeed, gold's behaviour especially in the past 15 months has been very much
driven by developments in the US, which helps explains why gold managed to rally by
over 8% in 2016 despite a weak fundamental backdrop. We expect these dynamics to
continue this year. Our analysis further shows that gold is currently undervalued relative
to trend growth due to various factors. We continue to hold the view that the
correction in gold, as optimism on the US economy and fiscal hopes emerged after the
US elections, was overdone as the path of fiscal policy remains uncertain. (See
Moderating our positive gold view) Downside risks to US yields as a result of fiscal
disappointment would be a bullish catalyst for gold, in our view. (See Global Rates
Landscape: Cracks in the reflation theme)

PM11:06am

Gold fundamentals remain challenged, but expectations are likely weaker

11:06 am
PM11:07am

Physical gold demand continues to be relatively soft and this is compounded by the
emergence of scrap supply as prices drifted higher this year. However, gold market
expectations for physical demand are already quite weak following poor offtake in
2016. This suggests that 1) further downside is likely to be more limited, and 2) the
risks are likely to be skewed towards an upside surprise given current market
expectations. Trade data so far this year is somewhat encouraging. India's gold imports
in February were stronger than expected y/y and vs historical standards. Seasonality
suggests that trade flows due to be released in the next couple of months should offer
further insight into the health of underlying demand. China's gold imports YTD look
soft, in line with anecdotal information, albeit not significantly below the average. In
Changes in onshore premium in China up ahead should also provide a gauge of
interest, as the impact from supply constraints diminish.

PM11:07am

Is that enough gold?

BE11:07am

God, yes.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

You can have the Q&A version if you like Bryce

PM11:08am

In one hit

PM11:08am

And then we can say we've done gold for the year

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Q: Is gold sentiment turning?
Sentiment towards gold has been positive, but conviction and participation has remained limited. Market
expectations tend to be for a broad range, with an upside bias. Gold's resilience has been encouraging, and
we think the relatively orderly uptrend thus far helps to strengthen underlying sentiment. Nevertheless, we
would expect that a more convincing break beyond $1250/1260 is probably needed to encourage stronger
participation. At the moment, while there is limited interest to put on sizeable short positions, there is also
a lack of urgency to build longs as investors consider the potential for economic data to improve further –
potentially fuelled by US fiscal policy – and rates to move sustainably higher, which would hurt gold.
Q: Where is the balance of risks right now?
We see upside risks given light positioning and an underlying positive bias. This could raise the risk that
further build in upward momentum would result in investors having to play catch-up. However, we
acknowledge greater downside risks relative to our base case given: 1) the pick-up in interest in Q1 was
slower than we had anticipated; 2) upside risks to US rates amid fiscal policy uncertainty and recent shifts in
Fed expectations; and 3) the potential for EUR yields to exert upward pressure on global yields as political
risks clear and economic data continues to improve. We temper our forecasts, taking into account
developments thus far, albeit we maintain our overall bullish outlook and broader narrative.
Q: Are gold fundamentals improving?
Demand indicators so far have been somewhat encouraging. We don't expect exceptional volumes, but
given weak market expectations, we think the risk is more for an upside surprise. The fundamental picture
is likely to be less straightforward this year with crosscurrents in China and potential positive offsets in India
as well as signs that demonetization effects may be fading faster than we initially thought.

PM11:08am

There.

PM11:08am

Done

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Hm.

BE11:09am

I mean, geopolitics sure is scary! But I've only read about the ratcheting up of tensions as a footnote this morning to the Fed's overnight hawkishness.

BE11:09am

As we've observed often, investors will fret for months about what Fed phrasing tells us about the future cost of capital but seem oddly blithe about changes in the probability of global nuclear war. .

11:08 am
BE11:09am

I guess you can only put the former in a spreadsheet.

BE11:09am

Anyway, buy gold. Or don't. I don't care.

PM11:09am

Just another thing we blame on QE

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Thumbs up

PM11:09am

But, yeah, the Fed

BE11:10am

Base case for balance sheet normalisation from December, rather than in March 2018

11:10 am
BE11:10am

And an intention to shrink the balance sheet via reducing both Treasuries and MBS

BE11:10am

Two more hikes this year.

PM11:10am

Key line...

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Most of the participants...anticipated that a change in that (reinvestment) policy would be appropriate before the end of this year

BE11:11am

........... And three next.

PM11:11am

Three next!

11:11 am
BE11:11am

That's JPM's assumption.

BE11:11am

June and September this year. June, September and December next.

BE11:12am

Wait, I'll grab the text for filler purposes.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Please do

BE11:13am

Sorry, for key insight.

BE11:13am

Fed fund futures rates mostly unchanged. Fed fund futures remained unchanged for YE17 week-over-week and marginally decreased for the years ahead. The YE17 fed funds futures rate stood at 124 bps, implying another 2 rate hikes in 2017. Meanwhile, the YE18 fed fund futures rate fell 8 bps to 1.59%, while the YE19 rate of 1.85% declined 11 bps. Overall, the market appears to be pricing in about 5 more rates hikes between now and year-end 2019. Currently, the markets imply a 63% chance and 82% chance of rate hikes at the June and September meetings.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Yield curve continues to flatten modestly. The 2Yr and 10yr US treasury yields declined 4 bps each week over week to 1.23% and 2.33%, respectively. The 2/10 spread edged down 1bps over the last week to 110 bps. Meanwhile, the shorter end of the curve increased marginally, with the 1M and 3M yields raising 2 bps and 3 bps, respectively. 1Q17 had similar dynamics as the 1M and 3M yields increased just above 20 bps in 1Q, while the 10Yr and 30Yr rates both fell.

PM11:14am

Prospect of five hikes over the next 20 months seems outlandish to me -- but I'm no expert Fed watcher.

PM11:14am

Were eight years into this economic cycle

11:14 am
BE11:14am

BE11:15am

You know that chart of predicted Fed moves vs actual? The one that looks like a fern?

BE11:15am

Markets tend to be wrong about this stuff.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Anyway, surely that's enough macro.

PM11:16am

ok

undefined
11:16 am
PM11:16am

Unilever?

PM11:16am

Look what you've caused Bryce

PM11:16am

Now they're having to sell Flora cos of you

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Now, perhaps I've not been paying attention, but wasn't spreads always up for disposal?

PM11:17am

http://www.investe...1704060700157377B/

Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 3,962, up 22 (+0.56%), High: 3,979, Low: 3,882, Volume: 1.26m
11:17 am
BE11:17am

The more interesting stuff, arguably, is about unpicking the dual listed structure.

BE11:18am

Which would be very upsetting for the people who like to email me about arb inefficiencies between the Dutch and UK lines.

BE11:18am

Though I guess they've still got Shell.

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Do these dual-listing arbs still work?

PM11:19am

I thought they would have been put out of work by the machines

BE11:19am

I think it's one of those trades that works until it doesn't. You can needle out a few pennies, but not terribly reliably.

11:19 am
PM11:20am

(Le Chiffre - good point)

BE11:20am

Anyway, in strategic review terms this is all moderate and sensible.

BE11:20am

Pretty much exactly what the market had expected post the Kraft bid dying.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Deutsche incoming.

BE11:21am

While on the ‘tamer’ side of the many scenarios discussed in the run-up to today, we would argue that the various measures combined will result in high-teen earnings growth, putting Unilever well ahead of its peers.

BE11:21am

In line with our ‘base case’ assumption, management confirmed a 20% margin target for 2020. While restructuring charges are (somewhat disappointingly) moving back below the line, making for an apples-to-apples starting point of 16.4% in 2016 (rather than 15.3% reported in 2016), we note that the pending Spreads disposal will have a negative -50-100bps impact, implying ‘underlying’ annual margin improvement of +100-110bps versus the 2016 base (at a cost of €3.5bn nevertheless).

11:22 am
BE11:22am

They reckon €6-7bn for spreads.

BE11:22am

Establishing a net debt/ EBITDA target of 2x (1.4x at the end of 2016) Unilever announced a €5bn buy-back for this year and could ‘theoretically’ buy back €3-4bn annually (without considering the Spreads proceeds), although we would note that acquisitions have been (and will be) key to strategy.

BE11:22am

We rate Unilever a Buy with a DCF-based price target of €49 (7.4% WACC; +7% mid-term slowing to +2% long-term cash-flow growth). Risks are volatility in emerging markets, rising cost of competition/ raw materials and a slower than expected delivery of shareholder value following the strategic review.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

(@Penny: that's not unfeasible. Some stuff on the conference call about being more dynamic and quicker with acquisitions.)

BE11:23am

And Goldman.

BE11:24am

The higher EBIT margin target suggests 360bps margin expansion over 2017-20, or 90bps per annum. This compares to the previous target of 40-80bps per annum over 2017-19 but importantly excludes restructuring charges (whereas previous guidance included them). The statement indicates that brand marketing investment (BMI) is expected to be c.€30bn over 2017-20 which is a which is a c.200-250bps cut as a % of sales over 2016. As discussed in our March 15 report, we expected Unilever to reduce BMI to grow EBIT margins but we believe this creates downside risk to growth. We had assumed a 140bps cut to BMI by 2020 vs 2016 and therefore c.60-110bps of the 160bps higher EBIT margin vs our expectation for 2020 is due to lower BMI.

11:24 am
undefined
BE11:25am

Pearson mentioned a lot on the right.

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 625.50, down 57 (-8.35%), High: 634.50, Low: 613.00, Volume: 2.17m
11:25 am
PM11:25am

So only part of this is the divi?

PM11:26am

going ex

BE11:26am

Well, it is indeed ex a 34p div, which accounts for most of that fall.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

But there's a couple of other things to accelerate it.

PM11:26am

Exane downgrade?

BE11:26am

That's one of them, yes.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Albeit still trading close to 10-year lows, Pearson shares have rebounded by c20% from their January trough. We find this unwarranted as we are increasingly sceptical about the group’s ability to return to growth in North America this decade. Faced with structural challenges in several of its segments, the shares are not cheap. We cut our TP to 550p and downgrade to Underperform.

BE11:27am

Structural pressures in US higher education courseware are now well discounted in the share price. However, we raise fresh concerns on the sustainability of double-digit growth in Pearson’s US virtual schools business, its fastest growing segment in North America, currently accounting for 6% of group revenues. Our analysis of Open Educational Resources penetration in US schools suggests a rising risk to US school courseware revenues (9% of group sales). Over a million K12 students are now in schools which are in the process of implementing an OER policy.

BE11:28am

(No, I don't know what a virtual school is.)

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Didn't Exane include Pearson in some sort of Xmas cracker selection -- or was that 15 months ago?

BE11:28am

English services and courseware are challenged too

Online language learning platforms are gaining share against traditional language schools and English courseware businesses, which does not bode well for Pearson’s English revenue growth.

BE11:28am

..... Did they? Maybe. I forget.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Whichever way, they're now well below consensus.

PM11:28am

Yeah, think they did. We were appalled at the time

BE11:29am

We lower our organic growth forecasts by c.80bp pa to -1.6% in FY17, -1% in FY18 and 0% in FY19. Consequently, we cut our 2018e EPS by 5% and 2019e EPS by 7%. We now stand at the low end of guidance for the current year and 5% below consensus EPS for 2018.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Adjusted for upcoming disposals and expected cash returns, we estimate the stock trades on 17.8x pro-forma P/E 2018e. That is at the upper end of European publishers and on par with Relx despite greater structural challenges, higher earnings volatility and lower visibility. We see c.20% downside on current share price levels.

PM11:30am

I was reading the Pearson renumeration report the other day. Really painful -- trying to justify Fallon getting a bonus.

PM11:30am

The basic argument was that he got a bonus cos he'd got nothing at all in the previous two years.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

A reward for persistent failure

BE11:31am

Okay, so "virtual schools" is a thing called Connections Academy

BE11:31am

There are 200 virtual schools in the US, operating in 26 states and enrolling over 200,000 of the 55m K12 students.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Exane's worried that they're rubbish.

PM11:00am

Welcome to ML

PM11:32am

But go on with Exane

11:32 am
BE11:32am

In the virtual school business, new school openings and enrolment growth in general is largely driven by regulatory considerations. We see growing risk on that front.

The main issue around regulation pertains to the academic efficacy of these schools Opponents argue that these virtual schools draw money away from traditional schools but fail to deliver on academic efficacy. Consequently they question whether tax payer money should be channelled into such businesses. For instance, in Colorado, nearly 42 percent of the 35 online schools failed to meet state-wide benchmarks for student performance, according to school performance ratings approved by the State Board of Education. In the same state only 12 percent of regular public schools failed to hit the state’s benchmark. Worse for virtual schools, only 10 percent of non-online charter schools failed to meet the state benchmarks.
Last year, the Walton Foundation (which claims to have funded a quarter of all charter schools in the US) sponsored three academic studies on the learning efficacy of virtual schools. The director of the foundation called results ‘sobering’. According to the Centre for Research on Education Outcomes at Stanford University ‘the students in virtual charter schools learned the equivalent of 180 fewer days in math and 72 fewer days in reading than their peers in traditional charter schools, on average’.

BE11:33am

That ....... looks ...................... bad.

BE11:33am

Advocates of virtual schools counter argue that these results do not adjust for social conditions (virtual schools tend to have a higher proportion of low-income families) nor for the fact that these schools tend to have a higher percentage of students joining in the middle of the year. We also point to the recurring high parent satisfaction scores published by Pearson’s Connections Academy (92%) as a positive factor. Nonetheless, we believe these studies are likely to influence parents and lawmakers alike.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

....... scandalous, arguably.

PM11:34am

Blimey

BE11:34am

Anyway, the third headwind against Pearson after the divi and the downgrade is this class action lawsuit that rumbles on.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

But you can find that yourself on Google.

undefined
PM11:35am

Oh look

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Tom Hunter has bagged Obama as the speaker at his charity gig

PM11:35am

In May

PM11:35am

That's quite a coup!

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Cripes!

PM11:35am

PRESIDENT BARACK OBAMA TO ADDRESS UK BUSINESS AND PHILANTHROPY LEADERS IN SCOTLAND

President Barack Obama, the 44th President of the United States, will address philanthropy and business leaders at a dinner in Edinburgh on 26th May 2017 at the EICC.

Hosted by the philanthropy, The Hunter Foundation (thehunterfoundation.co.uk), all profits from the event will be invested in charities supporting young people in Scotland.

PM11:36am

Sir Tom Hunter, founder of The Hunter Foundation commented; “From the South Side of Chicago to the White House has been an epic, historic journey and it will be a true honour to hear that story from the man who made that journey. We are both truly proud and delighted to be hosting the 44th President of the United States in Scotland at this event.”

11:36 am
PM11:36am

Hot ticket, I'd say

undefined
PM11:37am

Where next?

11:37 am
BE11:37am

(There's something a bit odd about that quote from Hunter. It makes sense, I guess, though the phrasing's strange.)

BE11:38am

Where, indeed, next?

BE11:38am

There's Allied Minds going below float price.

11:38 am
Allied Minds PLC (ALM:LSE): Last: 173.97, down 11.03 (-5.96%), High: 183.30, Low: 158.10, Volume: 1.63m
PM11:38am

Tullow ex rights i see

PM11:38am

http://www.investe...1704060700097053B/

11:38 am
PM11:38am

But yes, Allied Minds

BE11:39am

...................... Jefferies is sort-of knife catching in Allied

PM11:39am

What the hell is going on?

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Total loss of confidence married with very low free float.

BE11:39am

Plus, no reliable means of valuation.

PM11:39am

And bungled handling of the CEO transition

11:40 am
PM11:40am

I think the stuff CS highlighted about costs also caught the eye of a few people

BE11:40am

.... Because when your only means is the NAV then you write off more than a quarter of it, holding after that requires heroic confidence.

BE11:40am

But Jefferies, as I say, is mildly less negative.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Having turned negative at pretty much the right moment.

BE11:41am

New CEO acts decisively: We downgraded ALM on the expectation that the new CEO would want to cull the portfolio, to release resources and focus on the most promising portfolio companies. This has happened more quickly and broadly than we expected, but we see this $147m hit as decisive rather than panicked or precipitate. The seven businesses slated for closure/disposal include the trio we had identified (RF Biocidics, CryoXtract and SoundCure/TTS, but also Novare, Biotectix and Optio Labs, the latter another relatively large casualty.

BE11:41am

(@Lemmy: no one knows.)

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Burden of expectations on STT/SciFluor/FW: Post the changes above, focus will increase on Spin Transfer (c28% of FY16E portfolio value), SciFluor (22%), Precision Biopsy (15%) and Federated Wireless (14%), of which we feel that the valuations are demanding for all but PB. FY16 results and the next capital markets day will need to show milestones and a path to validated, ideally crystallized, value. STT appears to have fallen behind Everspin and lacks the promised memory major partner. SciFluor needs success in its Ph I’s to justify its value. FW clearly has established a core and exciting role in spectrum sharing, but the success and monetisation of the business, and timing are all unclear to us.

BE11:42am

Disclosure - not the time to hide: Previously ALM had signaled a plan to cut disclosure of portfolio values - we hope that the new CEO will draw back from this - it would be injurious to an already beleaguered share price and investor base, and rob the company of the scope to quantify gains which should now be possible (including on the businesses slated for closure or disposal).

BE11:42am

Following the share price falls which have accelerated since the CEO change and our last update, ALM is now trading below even our reduced estimated current Asset Value of 195p. With adequate cash reserves and a chance to demonstrate value and a plan for 2017 with the results 27/4/17 we have reduced our PT to 195p, zero premium to NAV, and hence upgrade from Underperform to Hold. Risks to the upside would be quicker value uplifts, to the downside failure at one of the core.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

(@BornCynic: arguably, they gave up Vodafone.)

BE11:43am

(@BornCynic: though it wasn't called that when they did.)

undefined
11:45 am
BE11:45am

....... in terms of news on the tape, there's Homeserve.

HomeServe PLC (HSV:LSE): Last: 617.50, up 51 (+9.00%), High: 639.00, Low: 571.50, Volume: 625.01k
BE11:46am

Decent numbers.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

And it sold off ahead of them on this FCA thing about having to be clearer about renewal prices.

BE11:47am

Because, if I remember right, your year two bill from Homeserve for boiler insurance is often stratospherically higher than your year-one bill.

PM11:47am

So like the car insurance industry?

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Yes, exactly.

BE11:48am

Though with less impetus to shop around, because who else does boiler insurance?

BE11:48am

Probably lots of companies would, but they don't bundle in their quotes with your utility bill.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Anyway, FY17 towards the upper end of expectations.

BE11:49am

Strategy update looks fine.

BE11:49am

Here's UBS.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Homeserve sees FY17e results to be at the top end of expectations: we increase forecasts 3-4% (UBSe PBT £112m vs. consensus £110m). This may mainly be due to FX, but trading has remained solid. New strategic initiatives are also all tracking well, such as US investments (e.g. 30% customer growth; USP target for $15m EBITDA reiterated), new partner signings (Aviva in the UK; Edison Energia in a new JV for Italy), or accelerating online positioning (via Checkatrade and Habitissimo). Management is also relaxed over regulatory changes in the UK, and overall we expect good performance in FY18e and beyond.

BE11:50am

All regions performed as hoped, and with a continued tailwind from FX Homeserve see results at the top end of consensus. The US delivered 30% customer growth with retention remaining at 82%; France delivered c5% customer growth with retention at 89% still as the new LDE channel adds to growth with Veolia; Spain saw c8% customer growth. The UK managed 1% customer growth even as retention came down to 80% as expected (greater mix of yr1 customers) – and market tests suggest no impact from coming regulatory change (must report previous year's price on renewal; Homeserve are already ahead of peers here as immediately on sign up it reports the yr2 price).

BE11:50am

At the last results meeting, the CEO said he was more excited than ever about Homeserve's growth prospects, and with plenty of strategic initiatives playing out successfully it is easy to see why. The main news today is around new partners, with a 51% stake in the Italian unit being sold to Edison Energia to form a JV (bodes well for future growth) and the launch of 'Aviva Response' in February. Technology also remains a focus, with LeakBot in trials with Aviva and 'More Than', and the recent investments in online platforms Checkatrade (UK) and Habitissimo (Spain).

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Homeserve trades on c17x Mar-19e PE, de-rating slightly after some recent concerns over the UK earnings outlook. We increase our estimates by 3-4% on FX and a small increase to UK customer numbers.

undefined
BE11:51am

@ROTR, we've been asked, and are asking around, with regards NMC.

11:52 am
NMC Health PLC (NMC:LSE): Last: 1,804, up 18 (+1.01%), High: 1,805, Low: 1,780, Volume: 27.68k
PM11:52am

(RuminationsOn -- i haven't followed closely enough)

PM11:53am

(Just feel for the guy doing 12 years, or whatever it was)

11:53 am
BE11:53am

There was a Caz upgade towards the end of last month, though it talked a lot about NMC being a regional consolidator rather than being a target.

BE11:54am

And the shares have rallied from the start of the year after the Abu Dhabi regulator reversed the 20% copay thing.

BE11:54am

I'd note that sector peer Mediclinic is at a 52-week low.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

(Though that's largely South Africa and rand exposure, I suspect.)

Mediclinic International PLC (MDC:LSE): Last: 674.50, down 4.5 (-0.66%), High: 677.00, Low: 666.50, Volume: 654.79k
BE11:55am

So .............. we're asking. Currently, dunno. But, yes, people seem interested in NMC suddenly for reasons that may or may not involve a deep understanding of the healthcare system in UAE.

11:55 am
undefined
BE11:56am

As for ASOS, also mentioned on the right ......

ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 5,505, down 195 (-3.42%), High: 5,628, Low: 5,285, Volume: 549.10k
11:56 am
BE11:56am

That's a Credit Suisse downgrade. Gone to "underperform".

BE11:57am

With distribution and warehouse costs +90bp higher
in the period 1H results have shown again how hard it is to achieve leverage in fulfilment costs at ASOS given the global distribution model and the need to keep investing in additional warehouse capacity and delivery proposition. Many of the drivers behind the momentum in the business over the past 12 months (US duty savings, free-returns, next-day delivery in EU and select international markets, A-List, FX etc.) also are now annualizing and growth rates will start to ease even as fulfilment and sourcing costs, capex and depreciation remain elevated.

BE11:57am

Valuation premium to European peers is at all-time highs. Particularly the c40% premium to Zalando looks stretched in our view given the widening margin profiles of the businesses over the next two years (consensus expects ASOS to see c50bp EBIT margin improvement to 4.7% vs. c100bp for Zalando to 7%) and the strong drop-through of EBITDA to cash at Zalando.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

We are increasing sales but cutting margin forecasts. For FY17 we raise our revenue forecast by 2.4% and cut operating margin by 10bp to 4.1% reflecting the strong topline growth in 1H and revised guidance (c30-35% sales growth) as well as higher costs in fulfillment and sourcing, and one-off transition costs leaving FY PBT forecast largely unchanged at £79.6m. For FY18 and FY19, we increase top-line forecasts by 6.7% and 10.1% respectively but assume a slower path to margin improvement than before.

PM11:58am

Didn't CS float Zalando?

BE11:58am

Did they?

11:58 am
PM11:58am

I think they did

BE11:58am

Target price revised up from 5100p to 5300p. Our new 12m target price is based on peer multiples (1.7x EV/Sales, 22x EV/EBITDA) and DCF (8% WACC and 7.5% terminal margin). With c10% downside to the current share price, which we think more than discounts the current momentum in the business and benefits from sterling weakness, and limited visibility around LT margins, we downgrade our rating to Underperform.
